results.title: Industrial Mysore. Series 2
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India, M. Bhavnani and Jagat Murari
results.brief_description: A further report on Mysore and its products, including carvings in sandalwood and ivory, inlay work, sugar, paper from bamboo pulp, textiles and soap. Work in the Kojar goldfields is shown in some detail.

results.title: Industrial Mysore. Series 1
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India, M. Bhavnani and Jagat Murari
results.brief_description: Mysore is one of the most highly industrialised states in India. Works include the Mysore Iron and Steel Works; the Krishnasagar Dam, where the river Kaveri has been harnessed; Sivasamundrum and Jog Falls; the state-owned porcelain works and power generating station; the aircraft industry and a factory for manufacturing telephones and electronic equipment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Documentary Films of India, M. Bhavnani and Jagat Murari

results.title: Industrial journey
results.creator_credit: Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production and Fred Clarke
results.brief_description: Surveys Tasmania’s secondary industries, transportation system, and hydro-electric power scheme. Includes carpet and paper mills, zinc and cement works the Mt Lyle copper mines, an aluminium plant, canned frozen and dried food factories. Shows how the ferry service to the mainland handles goods economically as road transports drive on board with their cargo.

results.title: Industrial Japan
results.brief_description: Japan’s economical growth is approximately 10% per year. Japan’s growth in the second half of the 20th century has been described as a miracle. Poorly endowed with raw materials it depends heavily upon its greatest assset - its people. They have developed industrial skills of the highest level and are applying them to the wide range of modern industry which make up the nation’s economic life.

results.title: Industrial dermatitis
results.brief_description: Methods of prevention and cure of industrial dermatitis, as shown through the work of a new Medical Officer at a factory where the disease is prevalent.

results.title: Industrial Canada
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB and Guy L. Cote
results.brief_description: A documentary account of Canada’s industrial development. The film traces the country’s transformation from a strictly agricultural economy to an increasingly industrial one, commenting on the impetus given by World War II. The Canada of today presents a diversity of industrial activity, with rich natural resources of every description forming the basis of export and manufacture.

results.title: Industrial Britain
results.creator_credit: Empire Marketing Board, John Grierson and Robert Joseph Flaherty
results.brief_description: In 1931, with Nanook, Moana and Tabu behind him, Flaherty came to London to collaborate with John Grierson’s new government-supported documentary unit at the Empire Marketing Board. By 1932, Grierson had recruited a number of young men to the unit who he coached on film projects. This documentary resulted from the collaborative efforts and contributions of such a team. The film celebrates the craftmanship of British workers and as it captures the skills of potters, machinists, glassblowers and other tradesmen engaged in their work. Photographed by Robert Flaherty with additional photgraphy by Basil Wright, Arthur Elton and John Grierson. Edited by Edgar Anstey and John Grierson. Narrated by Donald Calthrop.

results.title: Industrial beginnings in West Pakistan
results.brief_description: In response to a rapid expansion in population the Pakistani government has sought the aid of foreign technicians and advisers to widen the labour market through the development of new industrial products. Their goal is twofold: to utilise the ancient skills of Pakistani craftsmen and to train the masses of unskilled workers to meet the demands of modern technology.

results.title: Induced currents
results.brief_description: Through the use of both direct photography and animation, the following subject5s are dealt with: armatures, commutators, collector rings, telephones, mutual inducation, and self-induction.
